Buddha's disciples, the bodhisattva's nature is accomplished with little desire, anger, and ignorance, not jealous, not stingy, not troubled, not speaking harsh words, not wanting to be angry or playful, not fickle, harmonious and gentle, already approachable, naturally able to accomplish the most wonderful offerings to the buddhas, namely the wealth of necessities, giving to others, fully accomplishing hands, feet, head, eyes, and so forth.

translated: Namely, giving drinks to those who need drinks, food to those who need food, vehicles to those who need vehicles, beds, bedding, and other necessities to those who need them, clothes to those who need clothes, gold, silver, jeweled crowns, bracelets, and other adornments to those who need them, and even their own skin and flesh to benefit sentient beings.
Having practiced giving in this way, they dedicate that giving towards arousing supreme, perfect enlightenment. Although they give, they do not give rise to a mind of arrogance or conceit.
How do they uphold precepts?

They accomplish physical, verbal, and mental actions. Having abandoned physical, verbal, and mental actions, they skillfully avoid obstructions, are unimpeded and uncontaminated, and purely and single-mindedly uphold the precepts.
Although they practice precepts and dedicate them to supreme, perfect enlightenment, they do not give rise to a mind of arrogance or the like.
Good sons!
How do bodhisattvas cultivate patience?
Whether it is from the path or from the secular world, they are able to endure and tolerate scolding, binding, cutting, beating, and various habitual afflictions.
Having cultivated patience in this way, they dedicate it to supreme, perfect enlightenment. Although they cultivate patience, they do not give rise to a mind of arrogance or the like.
Good sons!
How do bodhisattvas give rise to the mind of vigor?
They think like this:

Just as the realm of space is immeasurable and boundless, the realm of sentient beings is also immeasurable and boundless. However, in this realm of sentient beings, I am alone and without a second, causing them to be peacefully established in the realm of nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.
For this reason, they give rise to vigor. The body does not separate from the body, and the observation of feelings.
Having contemplated feelings, they contemplate the activities of the mind;
Having contemplated the mind, they contemplate all phenomena in accordance with reality.

Having contemplated well in this way, in order to prevent the arising of unwholesome evil dharmas that have not yet arisen, they arouse desire, cultivate, strive with vigor, uphold the mind, and practice correctly;
In order to give rise to wholesome dharmas that have not yet arisen, they arouse desire, cultivate, strive with vigor, uphold the mind, and practice correctly;
In order to cause unwholesome dharmas that have already arisen to cease, they arouse desire, cultivate, strive with vigor, uphold the mind, and practice correctly;

In order to cause wholesome dharmas that have already arisen to endure for a long time, and to further increase and expand them, they arouse desire, cultivate, strive with vigor, uphold the mind, and practice correctly.
Having aroused vigor, they attain the first stage of the bases of supernatural power, and likewise the second, third, up to the fourth stage of the bases of supernatural power.
They attain the bases of supernatural powers and can abide for one eon or less, or fully practice to perfect the perfection of vigor.
Thus, having aroused vigor, they turn that vigor towards supreme perfect enlightenment.
Although they arouse such vigor, their minds do not give rise to arrogance.
Good sons!

Free from mental desires, free from mental cessation, free from desires for tranquility, not relying on the internal, not relying on the external, not relying on form, not relying on feeling and thought, not relying on consciousness, not relying on the desire, form, or formless realms, not relying on emptiness, signlessness, or wishlessness, not relying on the mundane or supramundane, not relying on giving, upholding precepts, patience, or vigor.
Good sons!
In brief, all conceptual thoughts and bonds are called meditation.

Thus cultivating various meditations, yet dedicating those meditations to supreme perfect enlightenment, although contemplating and cultivating these meditations, one still does not give rise to a mind of arrogance and so forth.
Good sons!

They think like this:

As taught by the Buddha, all dharmas are without self, without sentient beings, without life, without soul, and without person.

They give rise to the thought of the World-Honored One and the thought of a good and virtuous friend towards those who hear the Dharma, and give rise to the thought of the various oceans of the world;
They give rise to the thought of the preceptor and the thought of the teacher;
When the guide is lost for a long time, in the wilderness of the world, in the midst of difficulties, they are able to search and seek, giving rise to the thought of searching and seeking;
In order to open the eyes that have been long closed in the darkness of ignorance, they cause them to give rise to the thought of awakening;
When they have fallen into the mud of afflictions in the world, they give rise to the thought of rescuing them;
In order to act as a guide for those who have long lost the right path, they give rise to the thought of being a guide;
In order to liberate those who have long been subdued in the prison of the world, they give rise to the thought of being a liberator;
In order to treat those who have long been afflicted, they give rise to the thought of being a good doctor;
In order to cause those whose bodies have been scorched by the fire of afflictions to abide in cessation, they give rise to the thought of the great rain clouds.

For the sake of the Dharma and the causes of the Dharma, they are able to endure cold, heat, wind, rain, mosquitoes, and gadflies, and also hunger and thirst. Even if they see others receiving pleasant rewards, they do not give rise to a longing for happiness.
However, they think like this:
Only I in the world enjoy happiness, and I am able to hear the true Dharma.
For this matter and for these causes and conditions, they do not give rise to worry, sorrow, suffering, distress, and resentment, etc.
Having already been free from worry, sorrow, suffering, distress, etc., they give rise to this thought:
I am able to bear the burden of a single phrase of the TathÄgata's teachings, whether it be for one eon in AvÄ«ci Hell or less than one eon.
With such an untiring mind, they naturally do not engage in any practices, yet attain omniscience, and quickly attain the Buddha's teachings that have not yet been attained.

For this reason, the bodhisattva is called one who delights in all dharmas.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wishing to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
The greatly wise one delights in all dharmas and perfects the Buddha's disciples.
He is close to the correct and wondrous Dharma and does not give rise to weariness.
With a respectful mind, he seeks the correct Dharma, the profound mind of the Buddha's disciples,
And with the mind recollecting, he also manifests the correct and wondrous practices.

Good sons!
If a bodhisattva makes such contemplations:
'All dharmas are like illusions, because they deceive ordinary beings;

The bodhisattva's such contemplation is called the correct contemplation of dharmas.
At that time the World-Honored One, wishing to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
All dharmas are like illusions, deluding the foolish and confused;
Hollow and insubstantial, just like dreams - you should uphold this.
Dharmas are like the moon in water, also like echoes and other phenomena;
And like reflections and so forth - the wise are not deluded about them.

Good man!

Wishing to realize the Dharma, with right wisdom assisting the Dharma realm, using the same methods, skillfully observing and entering, skillfully upholding those characteristics, skillfully contemplating and recording.

Having skillfully recorded those characteristics, skillfully upholding, cultivating, and recording them, one naturally practices the activities equal to the Dharma realm. Feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are also observed as impermanent, but one does not become disgusted with consciousness and so forth.

the Dharmas of the Dharma realm are skillfully observed and penetrated, and those characteristics are also recorded, skillfully upheld, cultivated, and recorded. Having done so, one naturally enters the activities equal to the Dharma realm. As with impermanence, so it is with suffering, emptiness, and non-self.
Having observed form as impermanent, one does not give rise to fear, alarm, or other such things within form.
Why is it so?
Form arises from deluded thinking and inversion, but one truly understands it as it is.
Observing feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness as impermanent, up to not being afraid, terrified, or alarmed within consciousness.
Why is it so?
Because consciousness arises from deluded inverted thoughts. However, they truly understand this.
Good sons!
It is like a skillful magician or the disciple of a magician conjuring various illusory things, such as elephant troops, horse troops, chariot troops, and infantry troops.
The wise ones, upon seeing this, do not give rise to fear or alarm.
Why is it so?
Because they truly understand that these are the illusory creations of the magician, unreal, unprecedented, and deceptive.
Bodhisattvas are also like this. Having contemplated that form is impermanent, they do not give rise to fear or alarm regarding form.
Why is it so?

Because form arises from deluded inverted thoughts. However, they truly understand this. Having contemplated that feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are impermanent, they do not give rise to fear or alarm regarding consciousness.
Why is it so?
Because consciousness arises from deluded inverted thoughts. However, they truly understand this.
At that time, Bodhisattva Pure Stainless Sublime Pure Jewel Moon King Light addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

And having realized the Dharma realm, with right wisdom they observe and enter the Dharma realm and the various dharmas that assist it.
At that time, the World-Honored One told Bodhisattva Pure Stainless Sublime Pure Jewel Moon King Light:
Good man!

It is like a wise man who always deals with poisons, skillfully preserving them, skillfully concealing them, and skillfully cherishing them. Bodhisattvas are also like this. They turn their minds towards nirvana, moisten towards nirvana, follow towards nirvana, and approach nirvana.
Yet they do not realize that nirvana.

Do not let me regress from the practice of enlightenment due to this matter.

It is like a person who serves the fire god, and that person daily and nightly makes offerings of incense, flowers, and so forth, respectfully praises, and attends to them, but that person does not think:
'I serve the fire with offerings, respect, praise, and attend to them, and I take them with both hands.
Why is it so?
Do not let me suffer in the body or be troubled in the mind because of this matter.'
The bodhisattva is like this, the mind turns towards nirvana, moistens towards nirvana, accords with nirvana, and takes nirvana, but they do not realize nirvana.
Why is it so?
Do not let me regress from the practice of enlightenment because of this matter.
At that time, Bodhisattva Pure Stainless Sublime Pure Jewel Moon King Light said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
As I understand the meaning of the World-Honored One's teachings, a bodhisattva should abide in the world.
The Buddha said:
It is so, it is so!

A bodhisattva should abide in the world.
He asked:

How can a bodhisattva abide in the world without being tainted by the afflictions of the world?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
For this matter, I will briefly give an analogy.
Good man!
It is like a person with magical spells who, by the power of great spells, plays with evil poisons, snakes, and frogs, and so forth, but that person does not end his life because of this.
Why is it so?
Because that person is well-versed in the power of spells.

A bodhisattva is also like this. Practicing in the world, abiding in the world, having already abided in the world, by the power of the spells of great wisdom and skillful means, he lives together with the poisonous snakes of afflictions, plays with them, and acts, moves, sits, and lies down with them.
Bodhisattvas do not regress from enlightenment because of this.
Why is it so?
Because they have accomplished the power of great wisdom, skillful means, and mantras.
At that time, Bodhisattva Pure Stainless Sublime Pure Jewel Moon King Light said:
World-Honored One!
It is rare, it is rare!
Those bodhisattvas are able to not realize nirvana, and yet not be tainted by the poisons of worldly afflictions.
World-Honored One!
I now take refuge in those great bodhisattvas.
World-Honored One!
Those who have cultivated wholesome roots and heard this Dharma will give rise to a single thought of joy.
World-Honored One!
Those good men and good women have already been predicted by the buddhas:
'If they are able to hear this Dharma door.'
The Buddha said:
Good man!
When this Dharma was being spoken, five hundred bhiká¹£us who had not yet realized the undefiled state attained liberation.
Having attained liberation, he immediately rose from his seat, bared his right shoulder, touched his right knee to the ground, joined his palms towards the Buddha, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
Bodhisattvas are worthy of respect and homage.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
So it is, so it is!
As you have said.
At that time the World-Honored One, wishing to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Respectfully paying homage to the greatly wise ones, respectfully paying homage to those who have attained fearlessness,
Respectfully paying homage to those who have purified the eyes, respectfully paying homage to the Buddha's disciples.
Because of skillful means and supreme wisdom,
Bodhisattvas of great renown are able to transcend the stage of the two vehicles.
Truly understanding the aggregates, namely the arising and ceasing of consciousness and so forth,
Seeing the world's thirst and longing, therefore not realizing nirvÄá¹‡a.
